text:
2.0  Tenement Details 
 Location and Access 
 P24/3764 is located approximately 10km north west of Broad Arrow within Mt Vetters Station (Pastoral lease 
 3114/925).  It is directly west of the main Goldfields Highway and the Kalgoorlie-Leonora railway line and is 
 accessible through tracks running west from the Goldfields Highway, in the vicinity of Bardoc. 
 Numerous station and fence line tracks, plus old grid lines provide reasonable internal access from this road 
 to the tenements (Figure 1).   
 Tenement Status 
 P24/3764  is  contained  within  the  Mt  Vetters  Pastoral  Lease  (3114/925)  and  on  the  Kalgoorlie  (SH51-09) 
 1:250,000 and Bardoc (3137) 1:100,000 map-sheets (Figure 1).   
 Table 1 shows the tenement status.

21.text: The Kalgoorlie Terrane is considered to show a generalised stratigraphy similar to that below:

24.text: •  Felsic volcanics and coeval granitic intrusions

26.text: •  Komatiites, with cumulate units and interbedded felsics (ca. 2700Ma)

text:
The Kalgoorlie Terrane is considered to show a generalised stratigraphy similar to that below: 
 •  Conglomerates 
 •  Felsic volcanics and coeval granitic intrusions 
 •  Upper Basalt Unit 
 •  Komatiites, with cumulate units and interbedded felsics (ca. 2700Ma)

38.text: P24/3764  lies  within  the  Ora  Banda  Domain  of  Swager  (1997).  This  domain,  together  with  the  Kambalda

39.text: Domain,  forms  part  of  the  best  studied  regions  of  the  Kalgoorlie  Terrane.  It  shows  the  most  complete

40.text: representation of the stratigraphy sequence represented throughout the Kalgoorlie Terrane.

42.text: The ultramafic rocks of this domain contain the Siberia, Goongarrie and Highway Projects. The ultramafic

43.text: volcanic  rocks  of the  Menzies  region  form  an  almost continuous  sheet -like  suite of  units, extending  from

44.text: Siberia  to  Ghost  Rocks,  north-east  of  Menzies  (Hill  et  al.1987).    These  units,  comprising  two  main

45.text: formations, from the basal komatiitic sequence of the Linger and Die Group, within the Ora Banda Domain.

46.text: The sequence is regionally continuous, mappable in outcrop and by aeromagnetic data.

63.text: The  dominant  ultramafic  units,  the  Walter  Williams  Formation  and  the  Siberia  Komatiite,  are  described

text:
•  Lower Basalt Unit 
 This sequence derives from work carried out through the 1970s to 1990s of which Swager (1997) presents a 
 summary. The full sequence is not visible in outcrop, and some Domains do not appear to contain the full 
 sequence, leading to the appearance of partial sequences of north-easterly trending packages.  
 A series of regional deformation events are outlined in Table 2. Mafic magmatism is considered to be long 
 lasting due to layered mafic sills present within the felsic volcanics. The upper basalt is thought to represent 
 a fractional crystallisation from the komatiite layer, and thus is believed to have a different origin to the lower 
 basalt.  
 P24/3764  lies  within  the  Ora  Banda  Domain  of  Swager  (1997).  This  domain,  together  with  the  Kambalda 
 Domain,  forms  part  of  the  best  studied  regions  of  the  Kalgoorlie  Terrane.  It  shows  the  most  complete 
 representation of the stratigraphy sequence represented throughout the Kalgoorlie Terrane. 
 The ultramafic rocks of this domain contain the Siberia, Goongarrie and Highway Projects. The ultramafic 
 volcanic  rocks  of the  Menzies  region  form  an  almost continuous  sheet -like  suite of  units, extending  from 
 Siberia  to  Ghost  Rocks,  north-east  of  Menzies  (Hill  et  al.1987).    These  units,  comprising  two  main 
 formations, from the basal komatiitic sequence of the Linger and Die Group, within the Ora Banda Domain. 
 The sequence is regionally continuous, mappable in outcrop and by aeromagnetic data.   
 The overall stratigraphy of the lower part of the Ora Banda Domain is as follows (from Swager, 1994): 
 Mt Pleasant Sill 
 Victorious Basalt 
 Bent Tree Basalt 
 Ora Banda Group 
 The  dominant  ultramafic  units,  the  Walter  Williams  Formation  and  the  Siberia  Komatiite,  are  described 
 Mt Ellis Sill 
 Big Dick Basalt 
 Siberia Komatiite 
 Walter Williams Formation 
 Missouri Basalt 
 Wongi Basalt 
 Linger and Die Group 
 Pole Group

60.text: Fractionated, layered, heterogeneous gabbro, capped by dolerite and basalt.

62.text: Upper olivine orthocumulate (UOOC) with heterogeneous grain size and olivine packing density, and

64.text: Thick (300-500 m) medium to coarse grained olivine mesocumulate (UOMC) and olivine adcumulate

65.text: (UOAC).  Moderately sharp contact with upper UOOC.

66.text: Basal UOOC, up to 50m thick, gradual contact into overlying UOMC.

text:
The  contact  between  the  two  ultramafic  units  is  characterised  by  shearing  (talc  chlorite  schist),  local 
 presence  of  sedimentary  lenses  and  a  narrow  unit  of  pyroxenite,  gabbro  and  leucogabbro.  The  entire 
 sequence  youngs  eastward  (Swager,  1994).  The  contact  between  the  Walter  William  Formation  and  the 
 Siberia Komatiite marks the eastern limit of the nickel laterite mineralisation. 
 The model for the formation of this komatiite unit involves initial cataclysmic eruption of komatiite magma and 
 subsequent fractionation of the lava.   
 An idealised komatiite sheet flow stratigraphic succession in descending order is: 
 (non cumulate) 
 pyroxene cumulates (including harrisite) 
 olivine orthocumulate, thin heterogeneous units 
 olivine mesocumulate, upper 
 olivine adcumulate, thick uniform sheet flow sequence 
 basal olivine mesocumulate 
 basal thin unit olivine orthocumulate 
 NICKEL LATERITE POTENTIAL 
 Nickeliferous laterite, formed by weathering processes since the tertiary, is generally restricted to olivine ad- 
 to  meso-  cumulate  komatiites,  rarely  reaching  ore  grades  over  the  more  weather  resistant  orthocumulate 
 komatiite facies rocks.  Ore genesis is thought to be by way of weathering removing soluble minerals (MgO, 
 SiO2, Ca, K and Na) and elements thereby preferentially concentrating more resistant elements (Ni and Co) 
 within  the  extremely  leached  ultramafic  clay  weathering  profile  and  supergene  enrichment  of  Ni-Co 
 The  prospective  (for  nickel  laterite  mineralisation)  ultramafic  sequence  is  formed  by  a  range  of  komatiite 
 lithologies within a single thick, fractionated flow unit.  The stratigraphic sequence in descending order of the 
 flow units consists of:   
 Fractionated, layered, heterogeneous gabbro, capped by dolerite and basalt.   
 Thin (1-3 m) pyroxenite.   
 Upper olivine orthocumulate (UOOC) with heterogeneous grain size and olivine packing density, and 
 thinly layered.   
 Thick (300-500 m) medium to coarse grained olivine mesocumulate (UOMC) and olivine adcumulate 
 (UOAC).  Moderately sharp contact with upper UOOC.   
 Basal UOOC, up to 50m thick, gradual contact into overlying UOMC.   
 .

D3 regional shortening: E(NE)-W(SW) 
 Granite - 'post tectonic'; c. 2620- 2600Ma 
 (very few) 
 Granite - 'late tectonic' c. 2640Ma 
 D4 regional shortening: E-W 
 oblique dextral/reverse faults 
 east-west extension: restricted to Ida Fault 
 post-metamorphic orogenic collapse? 
 strike and reverse slip faults;  en echelon folds
